<|endoftext|>/*
Check if in given vector of numbers, are any two numbers closer to each other than
given threshold.
>>> has_close_elements({1.0, 2.0, 3.0}, 0.5)
false
>>> has_close_elements({1.0, 2.8, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 2.0}, 0.3)
true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <math.h>
using std;
bool has_close_elements(vector < float > numbers, float threshold) {
    int i, a;
   
    for (i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        a = i;
        for (int j = i + 1; j < numbers.size(); j++) {
            if (fabs(numbers[a] - numbers[j]) < threshold) {
                a = j;
            }
        }
        if (i!= a) {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer n, you have to make a pile of n levels of stones.
The first level has n stones.
The number of stones in the next level is:
    - the next odd number if n is odd.
    - the next even number if n is even.
Return the number of stones in each level in a vector, where element at index
i represents the number of stones in the level (i+1).

Examples:
>>> make_a_pile(3)
{3, 5, 7}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > make_a_pile(int n) {
   
   vector < int > pile;
   pile.reserve(n);
   
   for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
      if (i % 2 == 0) {
         pile.push_back(i);
      }
      else {
         pile.push_back(i + 1);
      }
   }
   return pile;
}

vector < int > make_a_pile(int n) {
   
   vector < int > pile;
   pile.reserve(n);
   
   for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
      if (i % 2 == 0) {
         pile.push_back(i);
      }
      else {
         pile.push_back(i + 1);
      }
   }
   return pile;
}

In this problem, you will implement a function that takes two vectors of numbers,
and determines whether it is possible to perform an exchange of elements
between them to make lst1 a vector of only even numbers.
There is no limit on the number of exchanged elements between lst1 and lst2.
If it is possible to exchange elements between the lst1 and lst2 to make
all the elements of lst1 to be even, return "YES".
Otherwise, return "NO".
For example:
exchange({1, 2, 3, 4}, {1, 2, 3, 4}) => "YES"
exchange({1, 2, 3, 4}, {1, 5, 3, 4}) => "NO"
It is assumed that the input vectors will be non-empty.
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string exchange(vector < int > lst1, vector < int > lst2) {
    int num = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < lst1.size(); i++) {
        for(int j = 0; j < lst2.size(); j++) {
            if(lst1[i] == lst2[j]) {
                num++;
            }
        }
    }
    if(num == lst1.size()) {
        return "YES";
    }
    return "NO";
}

Given a string representing a space separated lowercase letters, return a map
of the letter with the most repetition and containing the corresponding count.
If several letters have the same occurrence, return all of them.

Example:
histogram("a b c") == {{"a", 1}, {"b", 1}, {"c", 1}}
histogram("a b b a") == {{"a", 2}, {"b", 2}}
histogram("a b c a b") == {{"a", 2}, {"b", 2}}
histogram("b b b b a") == {{"b", 4}}
histogram("") == {}

*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <map>
using std;
map < char, int > histogram(string test) {
    map < char, int > count = {
        }
   , out = {
        }
    ;
    map < char, int > :: iterator it;
    int max = 0;
    for (int E = 0; E < test.length(); E++)
    if (test [ E ]!='')
     {
       
        it = count.find(test [ E ]);
        if (it!= count.end())
        {
            int count = it -> second;
            count ++;
            if (count > max)
            {
                max = count;
            }
        }
        else
        {
            count [ test [ E ] ] = 1;
        }
    }
    for (it = count.begin(); it!= count.end(); it++)
    {
        if (max < it -> second)
        {
            max = it -> second;
        }
    }
    for (it = count.begin(); it!= count.end(); it++)
    {
        out [ it -> first ] = max;
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/* Given a positive integer n, return a sorted vector that has the odd numbers in collatz sequence. The Collatz conjecture is a conjecture in mathematics that concerns a sequence defined as follows: start with any positive integer n. Then each term is obtained from the previous term as follows: if the previous term is even, the next term is one half of the previous term. If the previous term is odd, the next term is 3 times the previous term plus 1. The conjecture is that no matter what value of n, the sequence will always reach 1. Note: 1. Collatz(1) is {1}. 2. returned vector sorted in increasing order. For example: get_odd_collatz(5) returns {1, 5} // The collatz sequence for 5 is {5, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1}, so the odd numbers are only 1, and 5. */ #include #include #include using std; vector < int > get_odd_collatz(int Z) { vector < int > out = { 1} ; while (Z!= 1) { if (Z % 2 == 0) { Z = Z / 2; out.push_back(Z); } else { Z = Z * 3 + 1; out.push_back(Z); } } sort(out.begin(), out.end()); return out; } int main() { vector < int > odd_collatz = get_odd_collatz(5); for (auto i : odd_collatz) printf("%d ", i); printf("\n"); } <|/ a tags=c++,algorithm,collatz |> <| c |> The question was about a C++ solution, not a C solution. Given a grid with N rows and N columns (N >= 2) and a positive integer k, 
each cell of the grid contains a value. Every integer in the range {1, N * N}

lst_A[j] = lst_B[j].
It is guaranteed that the answer is unique.

    Input: grid = { {1,2,3}, {4,5,6}, {7,8,9}}, k = 3

<|endoftext|>/*
Return a greatest common divisor of two integers a and b
>>> greatest_common_divisor(3, 5)
1
>>> greatest_common_divisor(25, 15)
5
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
int greatest_common_divisor(int U, int b) {
    int out, m;
    while (true) {
        if (U < b)
            break;
        m = U / b;
        U = U - m * b;
        out = b;
        b = m;
    }
    return out;
}

int sum_squares(vector < float > lst) {

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_equal_to_sum_even(4) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(6) == false
is_equal_to_sum_even(8) == true
*/
#include <stdio.h>
using std;
bool is_equal_to_sum_even(int E) {
   
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 1; i <= E; i++) {
        sum += i;
    }
    
    if(sum % 2 == 0) {
        return true;
    }
    return false;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> special_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long special_factorial(int n){
    long long fact=1,bfact=1;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        fact*=i;
    for (int i=1;i<=n;i++)
        bfact*=i;
    return fact*bfact;
}

Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,
order them based on their index in original vector.

*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < int > order_by_points(vector < int > nums) {
    vector < int > sumdigit = {
        }
    ;
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)
     {

        int sum = 0;
        for (int U = 1; U < w.length(); U++)
        sum+=w [ U ] - 48;
        if (nums [ i ] > 0) sum+=w [ 0 ] - 48;
       
        sumdigit [ i ] = sum;
    }
    vector < int > result;
    for (int i = 0; i < sumdigit.size(); i++)
    {
        for (int j = 0; j < sumdigit.size(); j++)
        {
            if (sumdigit [ i ] > sumdigit [ j ])
            {
                int temp = sumdigit [ i ];
                sumdigit [ i ] = sumdigit [ j ];
                sumdigit [ j ] = temp;
            }
        }
    }
    for (int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++)

        string w = to_string(abs(nums [ i ]));
        int sum = 0;
        for (int U = 1; U < w.length(); U++)
        sum+=w [ U ] - 48;
        if (nums [ i ] > 0) sum+=w [ 0 ] - 48;
       
        if (sumdigit [ i ] == sum)
        {
            result.push_back(nums [ i ]);
        }
    }
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return a string containing space-delimited numbers starting from 0 upto n inclusive.
>>> string_sequence(0)
"0"
>>> string_sequence(5)
"0 1 2 3 4 5"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
string string_sequence(int n) {
   
    string s = "";
    for(int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
        s += to_string(i);
    }
    return s;
}

Examples: for x_or_y(7, 34, 12) == 34 for x_or_y(15, 8, 5) == 5 */ #include using std; int x_or_y(int n, int x, int y) { bool isp = true; if (n < 2) isp = false; if (isp) { if (n == 2) return x; if (n % 2 == 0) return x_or_y(n - 1, x, y); else return x_or_y(n - 2, x, y + 1); } else { if (n == 2) return y; if (n % 2 == 0) return x_or_y(n - 1, x + 1, y); else return x_or_y(n - 2, x + 1, y + 1); } } int main() { int n, x, y; printf("Enter a number: "); scanf("%d", &n); printf("Enter a number: "); scanf("%d", &x); printf("Enter a number: "); scanf("%d", &y); printf("%d\n", x_or_y(n, x, y)); } <|/ a dscore=0 |> <| c |> Thank you very much for your help. <|endoftext|>/* You will be given the name of a class (a string) and a vector of extensions. The extensions are to be used to load additional classes to the class. The strength of the extension is as follows: Let CAP be the number of the uppercase letters in the extension's name, and let SM be the number of lowercase letters in the extension's name, the strength is given by the fraction CAP - SM. You should find the strongest extension and return a string in this format: ClassName.StrongestExtensionName. If there are two or more extensions with the same strength, you should choose the one that comes first in the vector. For example, if you are given "Slices" as the class and a vector of the extensions: {"SErviNGSliCes", "Cheese", "StuFfed"} then you should return "Slices.SErviNGSliCes" since "SErviNGSliCes" is the strongest extension (its strength is -1). Example: for Strongest_Extension("my_class", {"AA", "Be", "CC"}) == "my_class.AA" */ #include #include #include using std; string Strongest_Extension(string class_name, vector < string > extensions) { string strongest = ""; int max = -1000; for (int y = 0; y < extensions.size(); y++) { int strength = 0; for (int j = 0; j < extensions [ y ].length(); j++) { if (extensions [ y ][ j ] >= 'A' && extensions [ y ][ j ] <= 'Z') { strength++; } else if (extensions [ y ][ j ] >= 'a' && extensions [ y ][ j ] <= 'z') { strength++; } else { strength++; } } if (strength > max) { max = strength; strongest = class_name + extensions [ y ]; } } return strongest; } <|/ a |> <| c |> Thank you so much for taking the time to write this code. 3
>>> how_many_times("aaaa", "aa")
3
*/

#include <string>
using std;
int how_many_times(string str, string substring) {
    int out = 0;
   
    for (int i = 0; i < str.size(); i++) {

            }
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Concatenate vector of strings into a single string
>>> concatenate({})
""
>>> concatenate({"a", "b", "c"})
"abc"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
string concatenate(vector < string > strings) {
   
   string result = "";
   for (auto s : strings) {
      result += s;
   }
   return result;
}

/*
Print a vector of strings
>>> print({"a", "b", "c"})
abc
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
void print(vector < string > strings) {
   
   for (auto s : strings) {
      printf("%s\n", s.c_str());
   }
}

/*
Print a vector of strings and a vector of ints
>>> print({"a", "b", "c"}, {"1", "2", "3"})
abc
123
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <iostream>
using std;
void print(vector < string > strings, vector < int > ints) {
   
   for (auto s : strings) {
      printf("%s\n", s.c_str());
   }
   for (auto i : ints) {
      printf("%d\n", i);
   }
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that start with a given prefix.
>>> filter_by_prefix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_prefix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_prefix(vector < string > strings, string prefix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(0, prefix.size()) == prefix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that end with a given suffix.
>>> filter_by_suffix({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_suffix({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_suffix(vector < string > strings, string suffix) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.substr(s.size() - suffix.size(), suffix.size()) == suffix) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

/*
Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain a given substring.
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bcd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

#include <stdio.h>

vector < string > filter_by_substring_length(vector < string > strings, string substring, int length) {
   
   vector < string > result;
   
   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos && s.length() > length) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }
   
   return result;
}

vector < string > filter_by_substring_length(vector < string > strings, string substring, int length) {

   for (auto & s : strings) {
      if (s.find(substring)!= string::npos && s.length() > length) {
         result.push_back(s);
      }
   }

}

bool is_prime(long long n) {
    if (n < 2) return false;

#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    std::vector<double> dxs;
    for (size_t i = 1; i < xs.size(); i++) {
        dxs.push_back(xs[i] * i);
    }

    auto func = [&](double x) {
        double result = 0.0;
        for (size_t i = 0; i < xs.size(); i++) {
            result += xs[i] * std::pow(x, i);
        }
        return result;
    };

    auto derivative = [&](double x) {
        double result = 0.0;
        for (size_t i = 0; i < dxs.size(); i++) {
            result += dxs[i] * std::pow(x, i);
        }
        return result;
    };

    double zero = func(0.);
    double zeroDx = derivative(0.);
    double zeroDxDx = derivative(zero);
    double zeroDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx);
    double zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx = derivative(zeroDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDxDx);

triples_sum_to_zero takes a vector of integers as an input.

sum to zero, and false otherwise.

>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 3, 5, 0})
false
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 3, -2, 1})
true
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1, 2, 3, 7})
false

true
>>> triples_sum_to_zero({1})
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool triples_sum_to_zero(vector < int > y) {
    for (int i = 0; i < y.size(); i++)
   
    {
        int sum = 0;
        for (int j = 0; j < y.size(); j++)
        {
            sum += y[j];
        }
        if (sum == 0)
        {
            return true;
        }
    }
    return false;
}

         if (i == j) {

      }

}

Please write a function to efficiently compute the n-th element of the fib4 number sequence. Do not use recursion. >>> fib4(5) 4 >>> fib4(6) 8 >>> fib4(7) 14 */ #include using std; int fib4(int n) { int C [ 100 ]; C [ 0 ] = 0; C [ 1 ] = 0; C [ 2 ] = 2; for(int i = 3; i <= n; i++) { C [ i ] = C [ i - 1 ] + C [ i - 2 ] + C [ i - 3 ] + C [ i - 4 ]; } return C [ n ]; } int main() { int n; printf("Enter the nth element of the fib4 number sequence: "); scanf("%d", &n); printf("The nth element of the fib4 number sequence is %d\n", fib4(n)); return 0; } <|/ a tags=c,fibonacci,fibonacci-heap |> <| c |> I like this solution. <|endoftext|>/*
remove_vowels is a function that takes string and returns string without vowels.
>>> remove_vowels("")
""
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef\nghijklm")
"bcdf\nghjklm"
>>> remove_vowels("abcdef")
"bcdf"
>>> remove_vowels("aaaaa")
""
>>> remove_vowels("aaBAA")
"B"
>>> remove_vowels("zbcd")
"zbcd"
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>
using std;
string remove_vowels(string text) {
    string out = "";
   
    for (auto &c : text) {
        if (c == 'a' || c == 'e' || c == 'i' || c == 'o' || c == 'u') {
            out += c;
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return true if all numbers in the vector l are below threshold t.
>>> below_threshold({1, 2, 4, 10}, 100)
true
>>> below_threshold({1, 20, 4, 10}, 5)
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
bool below_threshold(vector < int > l, int t) {
   
   for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) {
      if (l[i] < t) {
         return false;
      }
   }
   return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
brackets is a string of '(' and ')'.
return true if every opening bracket has a corresponding closing bracket.

>>> correct_bracketing("(")
false
>>> correct_bracketing("()")
true
>>> correct_bracketing("(()())")
true
>>> correct_bracketing(")(()")
false
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <string>
using std;
bool correct_bracketing(string brackets) {
    int level = 0;
    for (int m = 0; m < brackets.length(); m++)
     {
       
        if (brackets[m] == '(')
        {
            level++;
        }
        else if (brackets[m] == ')')
        {
            level--;
        }
        if (level < 0)
        {
            return false;
        }
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
xs represent coefficients of a polynomial.
xs{0} + xs{1} * x + xs{2} * x^2 +....
 Return derivative of this polynomial in the same form.
>>> derivative({3, 1, 2, 4, 5})
{1, 4, 12, 20}
>>> derivative({1, 2, 3})
{2, 6}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <math.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < float > derivative(vector < float > xs) {
   
   vector < float > derivative;
   
   derivative.push_back(xs[0]);
   
   for (int i = 1; i < xs.size(); i++) {
      derivative.push_back(xs[i] * derivative.back());
   }
   
   return derivative;
}

Filter an input vector of strings only for ones that contain given substring
>>> filter_by_substring({}, "a")
{}
>>> filter_by_substring({"abc", "bacd", "cde", "vector"}, "a")
{"abc", "bacd", "vector"}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
using std;
vector < string > filter_by_substring(vector < string > strings, string substring) {
    vector < string > out;
   
    for(auto it = strings.begin(); it!= strings.end(); ++it) {
        if(substring.find(*it)!= string::npos) {
            out.push_back(*it);
        }
    }
    return out;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
For a given vector of integers, return a vector consisting of a sum and a product of all the integers in a vector.
Empty sum should be equal to 0 and empty product should be equal to 1.
>>> sum_product({})
(0, 1)
>>> sum_product({1, 2, 3, 4})
(10, 24)
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > sum_product(vector < int > numbers) {
    int sum = 0, product = 1;
    for (int T = 0; T < numbers.size(); T++)
   
    {
        sum += numbers[T];
        product *= numbers[T];
    }
    vector < int > result;
    result.push_back(sum);
    result.push_back(product);
    return result;
}

From a given vector of integers, generate a vector of rolling maximum element found until given moment
in the sequence.
>>> rolling_max({1, 2, 3, 2, 3, 4, 2})
{1, 2, 3, 3, 3, 4, 4}
*/
#include <stdio.h>
#include <vector>
using std;
vector < int > rolling_max(vector < int > numbers) {
    vector < int > out;
    int s9w = 0;
   
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        out.push_back(numbers[i]);
        if(s9w == 0) {
            s9w = numbers[i];
        }
        else {
            if(numbers[i] > s9w) {
                s9w = numbers[i];
            }
        }
    }
    
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++) {
        if(numbers[i] > s9w) {
            out.push_back(s9w);
            s9w = numbers[i];
        }
    }
    
    return out;
}
